question: A 3-month-old child has acute diarrhea and is irritable. When his skin is pinched it goes down slowly. His mucosal membranes are also seen to be dry. Which of the following corresponds to the condition of this child?

A 3-month-old male baby was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with effortless spitting. The mother gave the history of on and off vomiting since 2nd week of life. On examination, weight was found to be 5 kg. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-week-old boy is referred for persistent vomiting. He was well until 5 days ago but is now vomiting after each feed, is not putting on weight, and appears jaundiced. After a test, he has a projectile non-bilious vomit. You suspect that he has pyloric stenosis and perform a venous gas and electrolyte analysis. What would you expect the result to reveal

A 3-year-old child comes to you with complaints of recurrent diarrhea since 8 months of age. The stools are bulky and foul-smelling. He was started on a complementary diet at 6 months of age. The weight is 7 kg. His Stool DR shows numerous fat globules. What further investigation you will advise to confirm the diagnosis?

answers.option: Tissue Transglutaminase IgA and serum IgA
Tissue Transglutaminase IgG and Serum IgA

question: A 3-year-old child was given one tablet three times a day to control loose motions. The diarrhea stopped but the next day the child was brought in a toxic condition with abdominal distention and vomiting. He had paralytic ileus, mild dehydration, low blood pressure, and sluggish reflexes. Which antidiarrheal drug could have caused this condition?

A 3-year-old male child presents with a history of constipation and abdominal distension for the last few years. The plain abdominal X-ray reveals fecal matter contained distended bowel loops. A barium study shows a transitional zone at the rectosigmoid junction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old alcoholic is brought to the emergency department with blood-containing vomit. He is given adequate treatment. After a few days, an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed which reveals healed longitudinal tears in the lower third of the esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

A 30-year-old female experiences an acute episode of right hypochondriac pain following a meal. She has had a similar episode in the past that was managed conservatively. On examination, she holds her breath on deep palpation of the right hypochondrium. On ultrasound, there are gallstones with pericholecystic fluid present. what is the best initial step in management?

answers.option: Keep the patient NPO, start IV antibiotics and analgesic

question: A 30-year-old female is brought to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. Two years ago, the woman had a lower gastrointestinal endoscopy, which revealed skip lesions and serpentine ulcers in the colon. Her pulse is 120 beats per minute. X-ray reveals air under the diaphragm. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of the current symptoms of the patient?

A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with Whipple's disease and discharged following a week of hospital stay and parenteral antibiotic therapy. What antibiotic will be prescribed in this case to be consumed for 12 months?

A 30-year-old female is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic for a severe upper respiratory tract infection. After a few days, the respiratory symptoms improve but the patient now develops abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and dehydration. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

A 30-year-old female presents with abdominal pain and bloody stools. On biopsy of the bowel wall, non-caseating granulomas are observed. She has a history of intermittent diarrhea and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with the complaint of shifting pain in the right lower abdomen for 2 days, which has become severe and generalized to the whole abdomen since morning. He is febrile, has three episodes of vomiting, and is unable to take orally. His pulse is 110 b/min, blood pressure (BP) is 100/70 mmHg, temperature is 100F. He has a tense tender abdomen on palpation with absent bowel sounds. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

A 30-year-old male patient comes into a rehabilitation center. He is an alcohol addict who wants to go for withdrawal treatment. What drug will you prescribe to this patient that will sensitize him to even a small dose of alcohol?

A 30-year-old male presents in the emergency department with a history of severe abdominal pain. His laboratory investigation shows amylase of 3000IU/L. Which of the following prognostic factors is unfavorable for this patient?

A 30-year-old man presented to his primary care physician the results of his recent screening, which he did for an overseas job. The lab shows the presence of Anti- Hepatitis C antibody. Which of the following further tests should be advised?

A 30-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with complaints of bleeding per rectum for 2 years. On colonoscopy, there was a diffuse inflammation of the rectum and sigmoid colon with superficial mucosal ulcers. A biopsy was performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man underwent surgery for a road traffic accident, during which the surgeon notices the presence of a submucosal mass in the ileum. On microscopic examination, mass is composed of nests of cells with uniform round nuclei and cytoplasm with small purple granules. Immunohistochemical stain chromogranin is positive in these cells. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
A 30-year-old unmarried woman comes into the outpatient department with a complaint of constipation. What is the doctor most likely to recommend for her condition?

answers.option: Tell her to eat more dairy products

question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with the complaint of a swollen, red, and painful left knee for the past two weeks. She has a 7-month history of bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. Abdominal palpation reveals tenderness over the left lower quadrant. Labs show a hemoglobin level of 9.3 g/dL. Microscopic examination of her stool reveals occult blood. A diffusely red, bleeding, friable colonic mucosa is visualized by colonoscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman who has a history of ulcerative colitis for the past 5 years develops severe lower gastrointestinal bleeding necessitating blood transfusions frequently in the last 15 days. She is advised to undergo surgery on an emergent basis. What should be the ideal procedure in this case?

answers.option: Total abdominal colectomy with ileal anastomosis (TAC-IRA)
Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch anal anastomosis (RPC-IPAA)

question: A 31-year-old female presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and diarrhea alternating with constipation. On stool analysis, a pale, foul-smelling stool is observed. She is advised to start a gluten-free diet. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female presents with an altered level of consciousness and irritability for one day. On examination, she is pale and jaundiced. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg, pulse is 55 beats/min, respiratory rate is 32/min. Tender hepatomegaly is also present. On inquiry, she gives a history of yellow discoloration of sclera & skin for the last 7 days. Lab results show a hemoglobin level of 11.2 gm/dl, total white blood cell count of 12000/mm3, platelet level of 332,000/mm3. Liver function tests show total bilirubin of 15 mg/dl, direct bilirubin of 5 mg /dl, serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase of 3000 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase of 680 IU/L, prothrombin time of 60 sec, and International normalized ratio= 3.5. She is in grade 3 encephalopathy. The most common cause of this presentation will be?

A 32-year-old female presents with the complaint of crampy abdominal pain and loose stools for the past 1 month with a frequency of 6-8/day. The stool was mixed with mucus and blood, with occasional blood clots seen. On examination, she has pallor and is lethargic. Her abdomen is tender in the right and left iliac fossa. A digital rectal examination shows a blood-stained finger with stool. Stool culture yields negative for any growth. Colonoscopy shows diffuse erythema of the entire colon with ulceration and spontaneous bleeding. Histopathology shows an increase in inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. The walls of the crypts of Lieberkuhn are infiltrated by inflammatory cells and there are crypt abscesses. What would be the most likely diagnosis in her case?
A 32-year-old man with hepatitis B refractory to treatments has begun an oral course of lamivudine. The mechanism of action of this medication likely involves which of the following?

A 35-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of abdominal discomfort for 3 months that was relieved on defecation. She also gave a history of changes in bowel habits with vitals completely normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female patient reports having epigastric abdominal pain for the last 7 months and has also lost 10 kg weight during this time. She is currently taking proton pump inhibitors (PPI) for her Barrett esophagus. She has recently been experiencing dysphagia and is a heavy smoker with no history of steroids or NSAIDs. What she is at risk of developing?

A 35-year-old female patient reports having epigastric abdominal pain for the last 7 months and has also lost 10 kg weight during this time. She is currently taking proton pump inhibitors (PPI). What is the next step in management?
A 35-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with obstructive jaundice. Her ultrasound showed stones in the common bile duct. What is the best management?

A 35-year-old male patient is planning a three-week trip overseas and asks for your advice regarding medications for traveler’s diarrhea. Which of the following drug is suitable for noninfectious travelers’ diarrhea?

A 35-year-old male presents in emergency, with severe abdominal pain since one day. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis one year back. On examination, his pulse is 120 beats/minute. Abdomen is tense and tender. There is free air under diaphragm in erect X-ray. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

answers.option: Colonoscopy and biopsy of terminal ileum

question: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency with complaints of severe abdominal pain and after evaluation, bowel perforation is suspected. His erect abdominal X-ray is performed. What is the most likely finding on an erect abdominal X-ray?

A 35-year-old man complains of pain in the abdomen for 3 months and nausea for 1 week. His stool sample is positive for occult blood. An upper GI endoscopy reveals normal esophageal mucosa, but a solitary 2 cm diameter shallow, sharply demarcated ulceration of the stomach is seen. Which of the following is most pertinent for this lesion?

A 35-year-old man experienced sudden nausea, vomiting, and extensive diarrhea with watery stools, about 5 liters/day. These symptoms led to dehydration, circulatory collapse, and anuria (lack of urine production) due to the rapid loss of fluids and electrolytes. Which of the following bacterium is the most likely cause?
A 35-year-old patient presents to the clinic with crampy abdominal pain, flatulence, and constipation. Which of the following should be avoided in order to improve the symptoms in this patient?

A 35-year-old woman complained of a month-long, off-and-on burning pain in her upper abdomen, which was moderately intense. She also experienced nausea and had vomited once. There were no signs of black, bloody stools, or vomiting blood. Biopsy results showed she had an H. pylori infection. What are the specific conditions needed to culture H. pylori?

A 35-year-old woman who immigrated to the United States from Pakistan comes to the outpatient clinic complaining of anorexia, nausea, and abdominal pain. Lab investigations reveal a positive hepatitis-B surface antigen ( HBsAg). She is then started on therapy with Adefovir Dipivoxil. To avoid resistance with which of the following drugs can Adefovir Dipivoxil be used as adjuvant therapy?

A 37-year-old female with mild arthritis presents to the clinic for a follow-up. She states that she is doing much better because of doubling her dose of ibuprofen. The physician warns the patient about peptic ulcers and bleeding from taking too much ibuprofen. She is offered alternatives, but the patient refuses because the ibuprofen works so well. What is the most appropriate therapy for this patient to prevent peptic ulcers?
A 37-year-old male patient is being tested. His reports show HBsAg=-ve, anti-HBs=-ve, anti-HBe=-ve, HBeAg=-ve, and anti-HBc=IgM reactive. Which of the following corresponds to this patient's results?

A 37-year-old man complains of chest pain after meals. He says this pain has gone on for a few months and gets only minimal relief from antacid tablets. The physician prescribes a drug that will decrease the amount of acid secreted by binding to and inhibiting an ATPase on the lumenal surface of parietal cells. Which of the following drugs works by inhibiting the ATPase enzyme?
A 37-year-old patient, on steroids for ulcerative colitis, is in sustained remission. He develops central obesity and a moon-like face. What is the next step in his management?

A 37-year-old woman with GERD and chronic hepatitis C genotype 1a infection is preparing to begin treatment with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir. Which is the most appropriate information for the patient regarding the use of a proton-pump inhibitor during treatment with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir?

answers.option: Absorption of ledipasvir is increased with increasing pH
The patient should stop using the proton-pump inhibitor
Absorption of sofosbuvir is decreased with increasing pH
Absorption of ledipasvir is not affected by gastric pH
A proton-pump inhibitor can be safely administered with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir without regard to timing of the dose or food intake

question: A 38-year-old businessman is on a trip to the United States where he develops diarrhea. He has to give a presentation in a few hours and needs rapid relief. He takes an antidiarrheal preparation containing loperamide. Which of the following is a property of loperamide that makes it useful in treating diarrhea?

A 38-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with a complaint of recurrent diarrhea. She is suspected of having Crohn’s disease. A colonoscopy is planned to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following will be observed in colonoscopy?

A 38-year-old female patient with gestational amenorrhea for 32 weeks presents in the ER with a sudden development of jaundice followed by an altered level of consciousness. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, and deeply jaundiced, but not oriented in time, place, and person. LFT shows marked Increased serum bilirubin with a marked increase in ALT, and AST levels. Which of the viral infections is more likely to be the cause of her rapid deterioration?

A 38-year-old female presents in the emergency department with a history of severe pain in the epigastric region and multiple episodes of vomiting for one day and gets admitted as a case of acute pancreatitis. CT scan abdomen shows a CTSI of 8/10. After 2 days of conservative management, the pain has decreased but she is not tolerating it orally. which of the following routes is preferred for nutritional support?

A 38-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of heartburn. He is sent for endoscopy which revealed pinkish mucosa on the esophagus near the gastro-esophageal junction. What is the diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man presents to the clinic with yellow discoloration of the sclera and skin. He had a transfusion 8 years ago and has had multiple transfusions for various reasons over the past few years. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain. On examination, the abdomen is soft and tender. An abdominal X-ray shows haustrations. Which part of the gut has haustrations?

A 38-year-old woman consults you before her planning to spend summer holidays in Gilgit and Swat with her husband and a 12-year-old boy. They never had hepatitis or liver disease in the past and none of them have had immunization against hepatitis. Which of the following plans would you recommend for the family?

answers.option: Screen all members of the family for Hepatitis A and B exposure
Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B vaccination for both parents and the child
Hepatitis A vaccination for parents and child and Hepatitis B vaccination for the child
Hepatitis A vaccination for both parents and child
Screen parents for previous Hepatitis A infection, and recommend Hepatitis A vaccination for the child

question: A 38-year-old woman presents with weight loss, evening pyrexia, night sweats. On examination, she has a lump in the right quadrant. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent attacks of mild diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain spaced by an asymptomatic period lasting for weeks to months. On physical examination, there are no remarkable findings. GI endoscopy reveals a thick rubbery intestinal wall. In addition, the radiography shows a string sign. Biopsies are performed in this region. Which of the following is the most classical finding of this condition?

A 40-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of aching pain in the abdomen anorexia, weight loss, pale stools, and dark-colored urine. Which of the following symptoms in this patient indicate obstructive jaundice?

A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain. She is unable to sit straight and the pain decreases when she leans forward. She is febrile and tachycardic. Abdominal examination reveals severe tenderness in her epigastrium. A diagnosis of acute pancreatitis was made. Serum amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Ultrasound abdomen showed a swollen pancreas. Which of the following laboratory findings indicate a good prognosis?

A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe pain in her right upper abdomen for the past 1 day. Pain radiated toward her right shoulder. On examination, she is febrile and has a severely tender right hypochondrium. Lab investigations show Hb 10 mg/dL and a total leukocyte count of 15,000/mm³. The remainder of her investigations are all normal. Ultrasound shows increased wall thickness of the gall bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 40-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with history of recurrent pain in right hypochondrium. Pain is aggravated with fatty meals. What is the mostly likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with loss of appetite, nausea, and weight loss for the last 08 months. His lab reports reveal SGPT 120, HbeAg reactive & HBV viral load 20,000. ultrasound abdomen is unremarkable. He is diagnosed with chronic HBV infection. Which of the drugs is used as first-line treatment of chronic HBV infection?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of nausea, and right upper quadrant pain. There is no history of jaundice. Laboratory investigations reveal a total leucocyte count (TLC) of 12,000 cells/dl with 91% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

A 40-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of jaundice, pruritus, and skin xanthomas. The senior doctor says that biopsy reports of the patient show elongated green-brown plugs of bile visible in dilated bile canaliculi. Some canaliculi are ruptured, which causes extravasation of bile, and droplets of bile pigment accumulated within hepatocytes, show a foamy appearance, also called feathery degeneration. Which of the following laboratory investigations can confirm the diagnosis of cholestasis?

answers.option: Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase

question: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with yellow pigmentation of skin and sclera. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's obstructive jaundice?

answers.option: Cancer in the body of pancreas
Cancer in the head of pancreas

question: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and confusion following an overdose of acetaminophen. He is alert but appears jaundiced and has mild abdominal discomfort. His laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, and he has a history of alcohol use. What is the most appropriate antidote for his condition?

A 41-year-old man has experienced progressive fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice for the past 4 months. He had a total colectomy performed five years ago. On physical examination, he is afebrile and scleral icterus is present. Cholangiography reveals the widespread obliteration of intrahepatic bile ducts. A liver biopsy is performed and microscopic examination shows periductular 'onion skin' fibrosis with a moderate lymphocytic infiltrate. Some intrahepatic bile ducts are obliterated, but there is no interface hepatitis. Which of the following underlying diseases is he most likely to have?
A 41-year-old patient presents to the emergency with hyperreflexia. On examination, his GCS score is 12/15. Which of the following is the correct grade of encephalopathy?

A 41-year-old woman has had diarrhea and fatigue with 3 kg weight loss over the past 6 months. On examination, she is afebrile with mild muscle wasting, but her motor strength is normal. Lab studies show no occult blood, ova, or parasites in stool. The patient begins following a special diet with no wheat or rye grain products. Symptoms improve on the non-gluten diet. What is the most likely microscopic feature seen in the biopsy specimen?

A 42-year-old female underwent an ultrasound abdomen due to non-specific abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows a well-defined anechoic lesion in the liver with posterior acoustic enhancement. No evidence of echoes within the lesion. The given explanation best corresponds to which one of the following lesions?

A 42-year-old male, smoker, obese, came to a gastroenterologist with a recurrent history of epigastric pain and retrosternal burning not responding to conventional treatment, taken for the last 4-6 weeks. He planned an upper GI endoscopy which showed reddish longitudinal lesions extending above the Z-line, and multiple biopsies were taken. Biopsy showed Columnar metaplasia in the esophagus. What is the diagnosis?

A 42-year-old man comes with a history of chronic intake of alcohol. On examination, he has a firm liver that is not enlarged. CT scan reveals a cirrhotic liver. He is then sent to a rehabilitation centre to quit his drinking habit. In spite of complete abstinence from alcohol, he most likely remains at risk of developing which of the following diseases?

A 43-year-old female develops severe epigastric and penetrating back pain following a dinner party. She was in shock when brought to the hospital. Which one of the following laboratory investigations would be most helpful in early diagnosis?

A 43-year-old man has had mid-epigastric pain and nausea for the past 2 months. On physical examination, he has no abnormal findings. On upper GI endoscopy, a solitary sharply demarcated 2-cm shallow gastric antral ulcer is seen. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?
A 45-year-old female is diagnosed with chronic cholecystitis due to cholelithiasis. What is the best treatment option?
A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of bloody diarrhea for the past 2 weeks. What is the least important diagnostic investigation in such cases?

A 45-year-old male is a known case of hepatitis C. He presents to the clinic with ascites, and jaundice for 2 weeks. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. Which of the following correctly correlates with his condition?

A 45-year-old male is presented complaining of vomiting off/on for one month. CT scan abdomen shows a cystic lesion in the tail of the pancreas compressing the stomach. Which of the following findings is indicative of the benign nature of the disease?

answers.option: Presence of atypical cells in cystic fluid
History of mild upper quadrant pain at least a month ago
Complex cystic lesion on endoscopic ultrasound
Cystic fluid amylase level of more than 3000 IU/L

question: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of bloody diarrhea with stingy mucoid material for 1 year. He also gave a history of lower abdominal cramps that were temporarily relieved by defecation. What is the gold standard test for confirming this disease?

A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with peptic ulcer for the last 1 year and is on maintenance therapy with antacid along with histamine (H2) receptor blocker. Recently, the patient came to the gastroenterology outpatient department (OPD) with concern that his cardiologist asked him to choose an alternative option for H2 receptor blocker because prescribed H2 receptor blocker can affect the metabolism of other prescribed drugs. Which histamine H2 blocker has the most marked inhibitory effect on microsomal cytochrome P-450 enzyme?

A 45-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension presents to clinic for a dietary consultation. He is concerned about his risk for cardiovascular disease and wants to improve his health. You explain the importance of the omega-3 and of omega-6 PUFAs in managing inflammation and improving cardiovascular health. Which mechanism describes how increasing dietary consumption omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) in comparison to omega-6 PUFA can contribute to reducing inflammation and the risk of cardiovascular disease?

answers.option: Omega-3 PUFAS compete with the enzymes that convert arachidonic acid into eicosanoids (PG, TX, LTs)
Omega-3 PUFAs enhance the ability of platelets to release TXA2, reducing the risk of coagulation
Omega-3 PUFAs inhibit the production of arachidonic acid, a precursor to inflammatory eicosanoids
Omega-3 PUFAs promote the synthesis of arachidonic acid, inhibiting inflammatory eicosanoid production
Omega-3 PUFAS compete with the inflammatory properties imparted by omega-6 PUFAs

question: A 45-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of heartburn, regurgitation, and occasional chest pain, especially after meals. He is diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) following endoscopy, which shows evidence of erosive esophagitis. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for treating his condition?
A 45-year-old male with a known case of hepatitis C develops hematemesis. He also has ascites. What is the most common cause?

A 45-year-old male with peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with an abrupt onset of severe epigastric pain for the past 1 hour. Abdominal examination raises suspicion for an acute surgical abdomen. Which of the following examination findings is not suggestive of perforation?

answers.option: A reactive pleural effusion is frequently seen with gastric perforation
Perforation accounts for two-thirds of peptic ulcer-related deaths
Tympanitic abdomen may indicate free air, confirmed by upright chest X-ray
Chemical peritonitis progresses to abdominal rigidity, bacterial peritonitis, and sepsis
Acute pancreatitis may result from posterior perforation

question: A 45-year-old man has had vague abdominal pain and nausea for the past 3 years. This pain is unrelieved by antacid medications. He has no difficulty swallowing and no heartburn following meals. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals antral mucosal erythema, but no ulcerations or masses. Biopsies are taken, and microscopically there is chronic non-specific gastritis. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be present in this man?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency room with wrist drop and foot drop. After evaluation, he is diagnosed with sideroblastic anemia. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be affected in this patient?

A 45-year-old man presents to the family physician with complaints of pain in the abdomen, especially in the right hypochondriac region. The pain has been associated with high-grade fever for 7 days. Ultrasound abdomen shows a liver abscess size of 10 cm x 8 cm. What treatment is recommended for his illness?

answers.option: Surgical resection of the liver abscess

question: A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with hepatitis B infection 2 years ago. Now he came to the outpatient department (OPD) for the follow-up. Recovery from hepatitis B infection is indicated by which of the following negative test?

A 45-year-old man with a duodenal ulcer was treated with a combination of drugs intended to heal the mucosal damage and to eradicate Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori). Which of the following antibacterial drugs is used commonly to eradicate this organism?

A 45-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c: 9.2%), obesity (BMI: 32 kg/m²), and hypertension (140/85 mmHg) presents with fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, and nausea. He has no history of alcohol use. Examination reveals mild hepatomegaly without jaundice or stigmata of chronic liver disease. Ultrasound shows increased liver echogenicity, consistent with fatty infiltration. Laboratory findings include mildly elevated AST (55 U/L) and ALT (75 U/L), along with dyslipidemia (total cholesterol: 230 mg/dL, triglycerides: 220 mg/dL). Given these findings, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.option: Recommend weight reduction and lifestyle modifications
Encourage moderate alcohol intake to reduce fibrosis risk

question: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with Parkinson's disease and currently on maintenance therapy with levodopa. Although his symptoms are well controlled with levodopa, but major disturbing side effects are nausea and vomiting. The physician decided to start an antiemetic that did not affect the antiparkinsonian activity of levodopa. Which of the following antiemetic selectively blocks levodopa-induced vomiting without blocking its antiparkinsonian action?
A 45-year-old patient presents with a mass in the liver, which appears as an anechoic lesion on ultrasound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of malodorous, greasy stools along with right upper quadrant pain. A percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is done, and the X-ray reveals masses in the gallbladder and cystic duct along with the dilation of bile canaliculi. Which of the following will have the highest elevation in serum when liver function test (LFTs) is done?
A 47-year-old man with a history of NSAID-induced ulcers has been placed on sucralfate. Which of the following compounds is related to sucralfate?

A 47-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue and dull, persistent discomfort in the right upper quadrant for the past three months. She is overweight (BMI: 31 kg/m²) and has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, diagnosed three years ago, with poor blood sugar control despite oral hypoglycemic therapy. She denies any significant alcohol use. On physical examination, there is mild hepatomegaly without tenderness. Laboratory results show ALT: 80 U/L, AST: 70 U/L, HbA1c: 8.4%, and triglycerides of 240 mg/dL. Hepatitis B and C serologies are negative. Abdominal ultrasound reveals an enlarged liver with increased echogenicity, suggestive of fatty infiltration. Which of the following is the most important risk factor contributing to the development of this patient's liver condition?

answers.option: Direct viral infection of liver cells causing inflammation
Alcohol-induced oxidative stress on liver cells
Increased hepatic fat accumulation due to insulin resistance
Excessive iron deposition in the liver

question: A 48-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department (ER) with complaints of severe epigastric pain for 1 day, which became generalized and more severe for 3 hours. Pain is associated with vomiting and even she is unable to tolerate a liquids diet. She has a history of NSAIDs use for osteoarthritis for a long period of time. Her pulse is 120 breaths/min, blood pressure (BP) is 100/60 mmHg, the temperature is afebrile and respiratory rate of 32 breath/min. She has a tense tender abdomen with board-like rigidity. Gut sounds inaudible. What would be the most appropriate radiological investigation to reach the diagnosis in this patient?

A 49-year-old male is admitted to the hospital and is showing signs of impaired neuronal function, rigidity, hyperreflexia, asterixis, and altered level of consciousness. Further history and examination reveal chronic liver disease. Which of the following is the most probable cause of these, manifestations in the patient?

A 49-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease and gastroesophageal reflux disorder has been treated with cimetidine for approximately 20 years. He now complains of breast swelling and breast discharge. Which of the following effects is the most likely explanation for his condition?
A 5-day-old infant presented with diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely to cause this?

A 5-month-old child presents with a history of recurrent vomiting mostly after feed but never containing blood. He is on mother feed with alternate bottle feed. He is admitted to hospital due to vomiting. He was a full-term baby and his birth weight was 2.7 Kg. On examination, the child is irritable with a current weight of 3.1 Kg and bilateral mild crepitations. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old child presented with a history of abdominal distension for the last 2 weeks. He has a history of recurrent foul-smelling, bulky stools containing no blood or mucus. He was admitted to the hospital two times with the above-mentioned complaints but didn't improve. On examination, his weight was 11 Kg, height was 99 cm, edematous child with hypo and hyperpigmentation all over the body. There was no peri-orbital edema, heart sounds were audible. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old caucasian male presents to the clinic with post-prandial abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, frequent oral aphthous ulceration, and weight loss for the past 6 months. He was advised upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy and colonoscopy by a family physician. The endoscopic appearance is suggestive of cobblestone. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old female comes to the hospital with complaints of right upper quadrant pain after eating fatty meals. In general appearance, the woman is obese. X-ray shows masses in the gall bladder. The presence of gallstones is confirmed and the woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which reveals jet-black stones that are soft and glassy in appearance. Which of the following is the major composition of the gallstones in this patient?
